awd_titl_txt: The Open Cluster Chemical Abundance and Mapping (OCCAM) Survey
awd_abstract_narration:
Astronomers are working to understand how galaxies change throughout the history of the Universe.  Our Milky Way galaxy allows the best opportunity to understand the details of a spiral galaxy's change over time.  To measure changes over time the investigators will identify groups of stars, called star clusters, for which they can reliably estimate the ages.  One key change is the chemical make-up of stars.  For this project, the investigators will assemble a large set of star clusters to measure chemical changes with time across the galaxy.  This project will serve the national interest as it promotes the progress of research in astronomy by providing a unique catalog to probe the history of the Milky Way.  The investigators will run outreach activities and add to existing programs at the Monnig Meteorite Gallery in Fort Worth, TX.  They will also train graduate and undergraduate students in modern data science research and analysis techniques.

The Open Cluster Chemical Analysis and Mapping (OCCAM) survey is a program to understand the chemical and dynamical evolution of the Milky Way by using star clusters as a key age-datable chemical and dynamical tracer population.  OCCAM will measure the dynamical and chemical abundance trends as a function of age and a function of position in the disk of the Milky Way galaxy.  They will test whether chemical tagging can work in the Milky Way disk and if open clusters participate in radial migration.  This project will use uniform photometry, cutting-edge astrometry, and chemistry from the SDSS-IV/APOGEE-2 survey.  Additional optical high-resolution spectroscopy will supplement the APOGEE data, adding neutron capture elements, to create a unique catalog of up to 400 open star clusters leading to systematically measured ages, distances, reddening, and detailed abundances for more than 20 elements.

por.por_cntn:
The 2010 National Academy Decadal Survey of Astronomy & Astrophysics identified key challenges in astrophysics, including "interpreting the 'fossil record' of galaxy assembly; mapping the flows of mass, energy, and chemical elements within galaxies; and characterizing the relationship between ordinary matter and the mysterious 'dark matter'." Interpreting the properties of other galaxies is difficult, especially as despite living inside the Milky Way, we do not know well basic quantities such as its mass, or its detailed chemical makeup. Any successful theory of galaxy formation must account for the properties of the galaxy we know best, the Milky Way, including its structure, the distributions of stars, gas, and dark matter, and the star formation history and chemical enrichment. To measure these properties, we need a key tracer, open star clusters , that can provide a detailed, large, and reliable tracer population that spans a significant coverage of the Milky Way galaxy.  However, one of the key limitations currently in the field is large systematic differences in results conducted with different instruments, and different research groups using different analysis techniques. 

This project, the Open Cluster Chemical Analysis and Mapping (OCCAM) survey, has created and analyzing the largest uniform catalog of open star clusters to date.  The OCCAM project is based primarily on analysis and follow-up of data from the ESA Gaia satellite and the Sloan Digital Sky Survey APOGEE survey, which completed in 2021.  The OCCAM project has created the largest catalog of open clusters with systematically measured ages, distances, and detailed chemical abundances for more than 20 elements.  We have used this powerful new data set to measure chemical gradients in the Galactic disk, and to determine how they vary as a function of the age and location in the Galaxy.  This project has produced new publicly available datasets and new analysis techniques that will continue to be used as new data is collected by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey V. The resulting uniform analysis and data set allows the establishment of reliable observational measurements that will constrain supernovae yields and feedback in the time evolution for the LCDM models of Milky Way-like galaxy disks, using the observed, time-sampled chemical abundance gradients of the Milky Way.  We have also used the open clusters in this project to work on improving stellar evolution studies, notably we have calibrated the carbon-to-nitrogen "chemical clock" that allows age-dating of up to 50% of all the stars in the APOGEE survey.

This project has provided a significant training environment, utilized cutting-edge big-data and developed new analysis techniques, for students at TCU's relatively smaller Astronomy program through connection to the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, however our broader outreach goals were limited by the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.  The students supported by this grant have been successful in starting academic and industry careers, including: Dr. John Donor, who was a TCU Graduate student, is now a postdoc at TCU working as part of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey V project, Dr. Amy Ray. who was a TCU Graduate student, is now a Support Astronomer at the Hobby-Eberly Telescope in Fort Davis, TX, and the Matthew Melendez an MS student, now programmer in industry.  This grant supported the Masters Theses of both Taylor Spoo and Natalie Myers, who are both continuing to their PhD at TCU. Also, four TCU undergraduates were supported, with two now in graduate school work towards their PhDs. The OCCAM survey was also assisted by four undergraduate summer research students who were supported by a TCU REU Site grant.
